issue.title: Support PR reviews
issue.body:
Hi! Awesome action, thanks!

Have you considered also supporting PR reviews?

Instead of hiding the comment in the "Changed files" section, this also starts a review and posts it in the conversation, e.g.:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15199031/110950534-4004c000-8344-11eb-835a-55b32ce05fe7.png)

comment.body: One way to do this would be to hook up the linter to reviewdog; then the framework handles all the different logic for things like github reviews and all this code needs to do is run the translation layer between reviewdog and swiftlint.

commits.message:
cd into app directory

This shouldn't be necessary since it's our working directory already,
but it seems it is.

Copy all files into the image

This should fix mnmandahalf/github-actions-check-ecr-image-exists#1 and
be fairly future-proof in that whatever files are created, they'll be
included automatically.

Clean up shell script

There were a couple latent problems with spaces in the inputs, but most
importantly if the go script failed, this script would not fail, and
thus that failure wouldn't be passed back through to Actions.

We should probably remove the shell script entirely and just have the go
script output things in the right format, but this is the first easy
change.

issue.title: Action cannot find go file
issue.body:
When I run this action, I get this error:

```
stat ecr.go: no such file or directory
```

It looks like that file, and possibly the other golang files, needs to be `COPY`ed in the Dockerfile.

issue.title: Some mypy errors are ignored
issue.body:
I have a mypy error that looks like this:

```
importer/flows/helpers/__init__.py: error: Duplicate module named "helpers" (also at "<snip>")
```

Currently this gets ignored because it doesn't have the line and column numbers that `-efm="%f:%l:%c: %t%*[^:]: %m"` expects.

Tentatively https://github.com/winnielabs/action-mypy/commit/42d48176d9ec3333b0d78952e070471ba6d25882 fixes this, but I haven't really tested this thoroughly to see what other effects that has.

I'm suspecting that if mypy gets json output (as per #38), then that would fix this as well.  But the upstream PR is a year old now and there's no decision-making from the core mypy team about what would be needed for it to get merged, so I'm not hopeful about that happening soon.

commits.message:
Maybe fix support for some mypy errors

There are errors that don't include line number or column number, so
previously they would get silently ignored.  I _think_ this might fix
that.

Use our fork of reviewdog

See winnielabs/reviewdog@aa9fdaa for details.

issue.title: How does the plugin detect which task it has to be attached to?
issue.body:
I'm currently trying to implement the plugin into our Asana board

The main question really is how the github action can correctly attach itself to a certain task without using any kind of ID, or something?

How does it know to attach to a certain task instead of another one? Does it use the title for that or something like that? Or do we have to manually attach it using the "github PR" field inside the task?

comment.body: I _think_ it will attempt to attach to **every** Asana task url it finds in the description.  I haven't thoroughly tested this and I don't really understand typescript, but that matches what I've seen.

issue.title: Switch documentation from rst to md, improve examples and readability.
issue.body: Is there a good reason to use a Python-y doc format for a PHP project on github? Markdown seems like the natural choice.

comment.body:
To come back to this years later :), because Read The Docs was a good documentation-hosting site, it uses Sphinx, and Sphinx at the time only supported ReST.

Sphinx appears to have some level of markdown support these days, so that would be a thing to look into. Alternatively, mkdocs might be a sufficient replacement for RTD and could be published onto GitHub Pages. I don't know offhand what the api documentation story is for mkdocs.

issue.title: import of ELB ListenerRule does not correctly fill out Listener ARN

labels.name: needs-triage

labels.name: kind/bug

issue.body:
### What happened?

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

### Expected Behavior

1. When doing `pulumi import`, I expected the generated code to be exactly matching the existing component in AWS and to not generate any warnings.
2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.
3. When executing the change, I expected it to not produce an error.
4. Importing a component should not put my stack in a state where I can no longer run my pulumi program without deleting my imported (and in use) resource.

### Actual Behavior

1. I imported two Listeners: `[$]> pulumi import aws-native:elasticloadbalancingv2:Listener winnielabs-web-80 arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:us-west-2:755158074228:listener/app/winnielabs-web/aeba2740bb970eea/
f591a0c11ef000fd` and `[$]> pulumi import aws-native:elasticloadbalancingv2:Listener winnielabs-web-443 arn:aws:elasticloadbalancing:us-west-2:755158074228:listener/app/winnielabs-web/aeba2740bb970eea
/ce17cdcd5978a7ad`
including adding the generated code to my Pulumi program and running `pulumi up`.  There were no changes on the `up` operation.
2. I ran an import of one of the rules attached to the first listener:

```

3. I added the generated code, but then changed `listener_arn=""` to `listener_arn=winnielabs_web_80` to reference the already-imported listener.
4. I ran `pulumi up` and saw that it wanted to add the field.  This seemed like an error in the state to me (the rule was created as part of the listener and is indeed attached) and so I told it to continue.  This returned an error because that is an immutable field:

comment.body: As a note, when `pulumi import` told me that the verification step had failed, I interpreted that as "you'll need to adjust the generated code in order to get it correctly generating a zero-diff configuration", not as "neither the generated code _nor_ the imported state will have the correct mapping of what's in aws, so you'll have to execute change operations on the aws api" (which I think is what happened).  Those are subtly different and the second is rather more dangerous, and if I'd understood that I would've aborted the import.  So there might be some clarity work to do on the warning message there.

### What happened?

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

### Expected Behavior

1. When doing `pulumi import`, I expected the generated code to be exactly matching the existing component in AWS and to not generate any warnings.
2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.
3. When executing the change, I expected it to not produce an error.

fix(deps): update golang.org/x/build digest to 812c061

Fail noisily on GitHub token failures

This is a hacky fix for reviewdog/reviewdog#1210 and a partial revert of
reviewdog/reviewdog#411.

The logic for determining if a GitHub token is read-only is flawed.
Specifically it is looking to see if the PR is coming from a fork,
because in the past those were never supported.  That is no longer true,
as GitHub has added a setting to allow passing secrets to forks (which
you would do if all forks are trusted, like in a fork-based workflow
inside a company).

The idea itself is problematic because it's always going to require
keeping up to date with whatever logic GitHub is using on their backend,
so a "try it and see if it fails" approach would be more
forward-looking.

But beyond that, the entire idea of failing gracefully is an issue.  If
everything is configured correctly, great.  But if someone has
misconfigured the token, the only way they'd find out is if they go
digging into the logs on the Action; otherwise it just looks like it's
operating correctly and there are no linter warnings.  This is a problem
because it means we need to create additional monitoring on reviewdog to
see if it's working correctly, rather than just relying on the PR check
status and getting user reports when the job is failing.

An actual fix here would also strip out
`cienv.HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` and the library code that was
pulled in to handle this.  I don't know Go very well and so I've opted
to make the smallest hack I can to get this working for our situation
while waiting on the discussion about how to handle this upstream.

issue.title: reviewdog erroneously falls back to logging on forked repo even when it has write permissions
issue.body:
I'm debugging Github Actions jobs where the token has write permissions:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375476-b870b57a-b101-4921-95f5-5193d28083ce.png)

but reviewdog says it does not, and only logs messages:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375569-d862c5c1-4b87-4f16-ad59-10bf5d54f064.png)

I've traced this down in code.  The github-pr-review reporter [checks to see if the token is read-only](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cmd/reviewdog/main.go#L282-L287).  `HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` however [only checks to see if it's in a fork](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cienv/github_actions.go#L115-L116).  However, github [now provides a way](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#modifying-the-permissions-for-the-github_token) to send write tokens to forks:

> You can use the `permissions` key to add and remove read permissions for forked repositories, but typically you can't grant write access. The exception to this behavior is where an admin user has selected the **Send write tokens to workflows from pull requests** option in the GitHub Actions settings.

So, we can't assume that all forks won't have write access; it needs to actually check the access of the token, or alternatively, try to post comments and if that fails then do the fallback action.

comment.body: @haya14busa I decided to take a look at trying to fix this myself. My conclusion is that we should probably just revert 2238fbd1063f5d1050b6e746cf0c611d213549d9. Graceful degredation is nice in theory, but in practice it means that the error is hidden. I had a pr that should have triggered comments via action-shellcheck, but there were no comments and everything was green: It's only when clicking into the Actions run and digging into the annotations that there's any indication that it _did_ find linter issues. If something is wrong with the Github tokens, no one is ever going to know unless the job starts failing. (And also there's the initial root issue reported here, which is that the check is incorrect and there actually _is_ permission in this case. But if we get rid of the check then that bypasses the bug.)

issue.title: Remove SSLv2 and SSLv3 support
issue.body:
This is a follow-up to #596 and the fix in #597.

Upstream [has removed support](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl/blob/main/CHANGELOG.rst#2210-2022-09-25) for SSLv2 and SSLv3.  Currently selenium-wire has a pinned version that prevents the upgrade, but sooner or later we'll want to be able to pull in updated versions.

In terms of the protocols, both of those are absolutely ancient.  TLS 1.0 was formally defined in 1999, and I think [all the browser vendors have killed off TLS 1.0 and 1.1](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/10/browser-vendors-unite-to-end-support-for-20-year-old-tls-1-0/) for a few years now - and those are the versions _after_ SSLv2 and v3!  When we look at [surveys of the internet](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssl-pulse/), practically no sites even support SSLv2 and v3 even if the clients did.  So I think it would be highly, highly unlikely that anyone would even notice that selenium-wire dropped support for those.

issue.title: Python type name inconsistency in documentation when used as an input
Class name inconsistency in documentation

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Needs attention from the triage team

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Some behavior is incorrect or out of spec

issue.body:
### What happened?

While creating an ECS Task Definition, the container definition class has two different names on the page and that makes it confusing as to which one to actually use.

### Steps to reproduce

On https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#container_definitions_python we see `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354134-c4c3c8c7-ecd5-4234-8942-97fd92477676.png)

When you click that and go to https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#taskdefinitioncontainerdefinition , that gives us the name `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` (without "Args"):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354261-d123248c-8f68-4022-aabb-8ab700c094ff.png)

It appears that `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs` is the name that works in code.

### Expected Behavior

Everything should use `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`.

### Actual Behavior

There are instances of `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` on the page.

### Output of `pulumi about`

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Contributing

Vote on this issue by adding a 👍 reaction. 
To contribute a fix for this issue, leave a comment (and link to your pull request, if you've opened one already).

comment.body:
I thought I'd take a stab at updating this since stuff like this is usually pretty easy.  If I'm understanding the code correctly, though, it looks like there's one name used for an input class and one for an output class (not just in python, but the other languages as well).  And naming them to be the same, albeit defined in different files, seems like potentially a path towards problems.  I don't want to break actual code functionality if that's a convention used to separate the two different classes.

But if that's true, it would be nice if we could fix the leaky abstraction that's making its way through to the docs.

issue.body:
### What happened?

I identified that an ECS service I had defined was not working because I had forgotten to add [an execution IAM role](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task_execution_IAM_role.html).  Adding this to the Pulumi definition however produces an AWS API error.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create an `ecs.TaskDefinition` with `pulumi up`
2. Add or change `task_role_arn`
3. Run `pulumi up` again

Pulumi code:
```python3
def cannot_change_arn():
    ecs.TaskDefinition(
        resource_name='cannot-change-arn',
        container_definitions=[
            ecs.TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs(
                name="my-app",
                image="amazon/amazon-ecs-sample",
                memory=128,
            )
        ],
        # After the first run to create the resource, uncomment this line to
        # try to update the object and reproduce the error.
        #task_role_arn='arn:aws:iam::1234567890:role/example',
    )
```
You can also clone https://github.com/xiongchiamiov/pulumi-bug-reports/tree/main/aws-native-python and call the function `ecs_task_definition.cannot_change_arn()` in `__main__.py`.

issue.title: Python ecs.TaskDefinition has a non-optional argument labelled as optional

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Needs attention from the triage team

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Some behavior is incorrect or out of spec

issue.body:
### What happened?

I was trying to create a minimal ECS Task Definition for use in a bug report, and was using the documentation as a guide on what the smallest amount of code I needed to use was.  There however is a field not required by Pulumi nor marked as required in the docs, which is actually required by the AWS API.

### Steps to reproduce

Pulumi code:
```python3
ecs.TaskDefinition('this is required')
```
You can also clone https://github.com/xiongchiamiov/pulumi-bug-reports/tree/main/aws-native-python and call `ecs_task_definition.not_optional_arguments()` in `__main__.py`.

Pulumi run:
```
┌─[jamesph@Jamess-MBP] - [~/Documents/pulumi-bug-reports/aws-native-python] - [Mon Sep 19, 03:28]
└─[$]> pulumi up
Previewing update (dev)

View Live: https://app.pulumi.com/xiongchiamiov/aws-native-python/dev/previews/9a74a600-179a-4cb1-ace1-2d251c769261

     Type                              Name                   Plan
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       create

Resources:
    + 1 to create
    1 unchanged

Do you want to perform this update? yes
Updating (dev)

View Live: https://app.pulumi.com/xiongchiamiov/aws-native-python/dev/updates/4

     Type                              Name                   Status                  Info
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev  **failed**              1 error
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       **creating failed**     1 error

Diagnostics:
  aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition (this is required):
    error: operation CREATE failed with "InvalidRequest": Invalid request provided: Create TaskDefinition: Container list cannot be empty. (Service: AmazonECS; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ClientException; Request ID: 44f47a4d-7fd5-40d0-97ac-55a7109fbbd1; Proxy: null)

  pulumi:pulumi:Stack (aws-native-python-dev):
    error: update failed

Resources:
    1 unchanged

Duration: 2s

warning: A new version of Pulumi is available. To upgrade from version '3.39.3' to '3.40.1', run
   $ brew upgrade pulumi
or visit https://pulumi.com/docs/reference/install/ for manual instructions and release notes.
```

### Expected Behavior

Based on [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), this is the only required parameter and the resource should be successfully created.  In reality, since more parameters are required by AWS, those should be marked as required in the documentation and Pulumi should provide an error before attempting to contact AWS.

For comparison, [here](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#inputs) is the equivalent documentation for the non-native package.  The container definitions list does indeed appear to be required, but interestingly the family does not.

### Actual Behavior

Pulumi attempted to create the resource and got back an error from the AWS API.

### Output of `pulumi about`

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Contributing

Vote on this issue by adding a 👍 reaction. 
To contribute a fix for this issue, leave a comment (and link to your pull request, if you've opened one already).

issue.title: ECS Task Definition ignores user-provided name

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Some behavior is incorrect or out of spec

issue.body:
### What happened?

I'm creating a task definition for ECS and providing a human-readable resource name so that I can recognize task definitions while looking in the AWS console.

### Steps to reproduce

Here is my Pulumi code:

```python3
"""An AWS Python Pulumi program"""

import pulumi
from pulumi_aws_native import ecs

task_definition = ecs.TaskDefinition(
    resource_name='winnie-web-task-{}'.format(pulumi.get_stack()),
    requires_compatibilities=['FARGATE'],
    cpu='1024',
    memory='2048',
    container_definitions=[
        ecs.TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs(
            name='nginx',
            image='755158074228.dkr.ecr.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/winnie-nginx:1.0.4',
            essential=True,
        ),
    ],
    network_mode='awsvpc',
    runtime_platform=ecs.TaskDefinitionRuntimePlatformArgs(
        operating_system_family='Linux',
    ),
    execution_role_arn='arn:aws:iam::755158074228:role/ecsTaskExecutionRole',
)
```
(This is a private image, but should work with [the public example in the docs](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#example).)

pip freeze:
```
Arpeggio==1.10.2
attrs==22.1.0
dill==0.3.5.1
grpcio==1.47.0
parver==0.3.1
protobuf==4.21.5
pulumi==3.39.3
pulumi-aws-native==0.29.0
PyYAML==6.0
semver==2.13.0
six==1.16.0
```

### Expected Behavior

I'd expect to see the task named something like `winnie-web-task-staging-<suffix>`.

### Actual Behavior

The resource is named `M0JVujF1TeMX9JUzAj3feASVC-I7fArcNDlnCE`.

comment.body:
@jkisk Yep, I had read that.

> If the name property is not available on a resource, consult the [Registry](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/) for the specific resource you are creating. Some resources use a different property to override auto-naming. For instance, the aws.s3.Bucket type uses the property bucket instead of name.

And as far as I can tell from [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), that is the intent of `resource_name` in `TaskDefinition` - it's described as "the unique name of the resource".

Task definitions _do_ have user-assignable names in AWS, so it would make sense that this would be used from the field in Pulumi.  If this is one of the resources that only uses autogenerated ids, however, that should be clarified in the documentation and the actual usage of `resource_name` should be covered - since right now it appears to be entirely ignored and unused.

issue.title: Support PR reviews
issue.body:
Hi! Awesome action, thanks!

Have you considered also supporting PR reviews?

Instead of hiding the comment in the "Changed files" section, this also starts a review and posts it in the conversation, e.g.:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15199031/110950534-4004c000-8344-11eb-835a-55b32ce05fe7.png)

comment.body: One way to do this would be to hook up the linter to reviewdog; then the framework handles all the different logic for things like github reviews and all this code needs to do is run the translation layer between reviewdog and swiftlint.

commits.message:
cd into app directory

This shouldn't be necessary since it's our working directory already,
but it seems it is.

Copy all files into the image

This should fix mnmandahalf/github-actions-check-ecr-image-exists#1 and
be fairly future-proof in that whatever files are created, they'll be
included automatically.

Clean up shell script

There were a couple latent problems with spaces in the inputs, but most
importantly if the go script failed, this script would not fail, and
thus that failure wouldn't be passed back through to Actions.

We should probably remove the shell script entirely and just have the go
script output things in the right format, but this is the first easy
change.

issue.title: Action cannot find go file
issue.body:
When I run this action, I get this error:

```
stat ecr.go: no such file or directory
```

It looks like that file, and possibly the other golang files, needs to be `COPY`ed in the Dockerfile.

issue.title: Some mypy errors are ignored
issue.body:
I have a mypy error that looks like this:

```
importer/flows/helpers/__init__.py: error: Duplicate module named "helpers" (also at "<snip>")
```

Currently this gets ignored because it doesn't have the line and column numbers that `-efm="%f:%l:%c: %t%*[^:]: %m"` expects.

Tentatively https://github.com/winnielabs/action-mypy/commit/42d48176d9ec3333b0d78952e070471ba6d25882 fixes this, but I haven't really tested this thoroughly to see what other effects that has.

I'm suspecting that if mypy gets json output (as per #38), then that would fix this as well.  But the upstream PR is a year old now and there's no decision-making from the core mypy team about what would be needed for it to get merged, so I'm not hopeful about that happening soon.

commits.message:
Maybe fix support for some mypy errors

There are errors that don't include line number or column number, so
previously they would get silently ignored.  I _think_ this might fix
that.

Use our fork of reviewdog

See winnielabs/reviewdog@aa9fdaa for details.

issue.title: How does the plugin detect which task it has to be attached to?
issue.body:
I'm currently trying to implement the plugin into our Asana board

The main question really is how the github action can correctly attach itself to a certain task without using any kind of ID, or something?

How does it know to attach to a certain task instead of another one? Does it use the title for that or something like that? Or do we have to manually attach it using the "github PR" field inside the task?

comment.body: I _think_ it will attempt to attach to **every** Asana task url it finds in the description.  I haven't thoroughly tested this and I don't really understand typescript, but that matches what I've seen.

issue.title: Switch documentation from rst to md, improve examples and readability.
issue.body: Is there a good reason to use a Python-y doc format for a PHP project on github? Markdown seems like the natural choice.

comment.body:
To come back to this years later :), because Read The Docs was a good documentation-hosting site, it uses Sphinx, and Sphinx at the time only supported ReST.

Sphinx appears to have some level of markdown support these days, so that would be a thing to look into. Alternatively, mkdocs might be a sufficient replacement for RTD and could be published onto GitHub Pages. I don't know offhand what the api documentation story is for mkdocs.

issue.body:
### What happened?

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

### Expected Behavior

1. When doing `pulumi import`, I expected the generated code to be exactly matching the existing component in AWS and to not generate any warnings.
2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.
3. When executing the change, I expected it to not produce an error.
4. Importing a component should not put my stack in a state where I can no longer run my pulumi program without deleting my imported (and in use) resource.

comment.body: As a note, when `pulumi import` told me that the verification step had failed, I interpreted that as "you'll need to adjust the generated code in order to get it correctly generating a zero-diff configuration", not as "neither the generated code _nor_ the imported state will have the correct mapping of what's in aws, so you'll have to execute change operations on the aws api" (which I think is what happened).  Those are subtly different and the second is rather more dangerous, and if I'd understood that I would've aborted the import.  So there might be some clarity work to do on the warning message there.

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.

fix(deps): update golang.org/x/build digest to 812c061

Fail noisily on GitHub token failures

This is a hacky fix for reviewdog/reviewdog#1210 and a partial revert of
reviewdog/reviewdog#411.

The logic for determining if a GitHub token is read-only is flawed.
Specifically it is looking to see if the PR is coming from a fork,
because in the past those were never supported.  That is no longer true,
as GitHub has added a setting to allow passing secrets to forks (which
you would do if all forks are trusted, like in a fork-based workflow
inside a company).

The idea itself is problematic because it's always going to require
keeping up to date with whatever logic GitHub is using on their backend,
so a "try it and see if it fails" approach would be more
forward-looking.

But beyond that, the entire idea of failing gracefully is an issue.  If
everything is configured correctly, great.  But if someone has
misconfigured the token, the only way they'd find out is if they go
digging into the logs on the Action; otherwise it just looks like it's
operating correctly and there are no linter warnings.  This is a problem
because it means we need to create additional monitoring on reviewdog to
see if it's working correctly, rather than just relying on the PR check
status and getting user reports when the job is failing.

An actual fix here would also strip out
`cienv.HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` and the library code that was
pulled in to handle this.  I don't know Go very well and so I've opted
to make the smallest hack I can to get this working for our situation
while waiting on the discussion about how to handle this upstream.

issue.title: reviewdog erroneously falls back to logging on forked repo even when it has write permissions
issue.body:
I'm debugging Github Actions jobs where the token has write permissions:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375476-b870b57a-b101-4921-95f5-5193d28083ce.png)

but reviewdog says it does not, and only logs messages:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375569-d862c5c1-4b87-4f16-ad59-10bf5d54f064.png)

I've traced this down in code.  The github-pr-review reporter [checks to see if the token is read-only](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cmd/reviewdog/main.go#L282-L287).  `HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` however [only checks to see if it's in a fork](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cienv/github_actions.go#L115-L116).  However, github [now provides a way](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#modifying-the-permissions-for-the-github_token) to send write tokens to forks:

> You can use the `permissions` key to add and remove read permissions for forked repositories, but typically you can't grant write access. The exception to this behavior is where an admin user has selected the **Send write tokens to workflows from pull requests** option in the GitHub Actions settings.

So, we can't assume that all forks won't have write access; it needs to actually check the access of the token, or alternatively, try to post comments and if that fails then do the fallback action.

comment.body: @haya14busa I decided to take a look at trying to fix this myself. My conclusion is that we should probably just revert 2238fbd1063f5d1050b6e746cf0c611d213549d9. Graceful degredation is nice in theory, but in practice it means that the error is hidden. I had a pr that should have triggered comments via action-shellcheck, but there were no comments and everything was green: It's only when clicking into the Actions run and digging into the annotations that there's any indication that it _did_ find linter issues. If something is wrong with the Github tokens, no one is ever going to know unless the job starts failing. (And also there's the initial root issue reported here, which is that the check is incorrect and there actually _is_ permission in this case. But if we get rid of the check then that bypasses the bug.)

issue.title: Remove SSLv2 and SSLv3 support
issue.body:
This is a follow-up to #596 and the fix in #597.

Upstream [has removed support](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl/blob/main/CHANGELOG.rst#2210-2022-09-25) for SSLv2 and SSLv3.  Currently selenium-wire has a pinned version that prevents the upgrade, but sooner or later we'll want to be able to pull in updated versions.

In terms of the protocols, both of those are absolutely ancient.  TLS 1.0 was formally defined in 1999, and I think [all the browser vendors have killed off TLS 1.0 and 1.1](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/10/browser-vendors-unite-to-end-support-for-20-year-old-tls-1-0/) for a few years now - and those are the versions _after_ SSLv2 and v3!  When we look at [surveys of the internet](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssl-pulse/), practically no sites even support SSLv2 and v3 even if the clients did.  So I think it would be highly, highly unlikely that anyone would even notice that selenium-wire dropped support for those.

issue.title: Python type name inconsistency in documentation when used as an input
Class name inconsistency in documentation

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Needs attention from the triage team

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Some behavior is incorrect or out of spec

issue.body:
### What happened?

While creating an ECS Task Definition, the container definition class has two different names on the page and that makes it confusing as to which one to actually use.

### Steps to reproduce

On https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#container_definitions_python we see `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354134-c4c3c8c7-ecd5-4234-8942-97fd92477676.png)

When you click that and go to https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#taskdefinitioncontainerdefinition , that gives us the name `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` (without "Args"):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354261-d123248c-8f68-4022-aabb-8ab700c094ff.png)

It appears that `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs` is the name that works in code.

### Expected Behavior

Everything should use `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`.

### Actual Behavior

There are instances of `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` on the page.

### Output of `pulumi about`

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Contributing

Vote on this issue by adding a 👍 reaction. 
To contribute a fix for this issue, leave a comment (and link to your pull request, if you've opened one already).

comment.body:
I thought I'd take a stab at updating this since stuff like this is usually pretty easy.  If I'm understanding the code correctly, though, it looks like there's one name used for an input class and one for an output class (not just in python, but the other languages as well).  And naming them to be the same, albeit defined in different files, seems like potentially a path towards problems.  I don't want to break actual code functionality if that's a convention used to separate the two different classes.

But if that's true, it would be nice if we could fix the leaky abstraction that's making its way through to the docs.

labels.name: kind/bug

issue.body:
### What happened?

I was trying to create a minimal ECS Task Definition for use in a bug report, and was using the documentation as a guide on what the smallest amount of code I needed to use was.  There however is a field not required by Pulumi nor marked as required in the docs, which is actually required by the AWS API.

### Steps to reproduce

Pulumi code:
```python3
ecs.TaskDefinition('this is required')
```
You can also clone https://github.com/xiongchiamiov/pulumi-bug-reports/tree/main/aws-native-python and call `ecs_task_definition.not_optional_arguments()` in `__main__.py`.

Pulumi run:
```
┌─[jamesph@Jamess-MBP] - [~/Documents/pulumi-bug-reports/aws-native-python] - [Mon Sep 19, 03:28]
└─[$]> pulumi up
Previewing update (dev)

View Live: https://app.pulumi.com/xiongchiamiov/aws-native-python/dev/previews/9a74a600-179a-4cb1-ace1-2d251c769261

     Type                              Name                   Plan
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       create

Resources:
    + 1 to create
    1 unchanged

Do you want to perform this update? yes
Updating (dev)

     Type                              Name                   Status                  Info
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev  **failed**              1 error
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       **creating failed**     1 error

Diagnostics:
  aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition (this is required):
    error: operation CREATE failed with "InvalidRequest": Invalid request provided: Create TaskDefinition: Container list cannot be empty. (Service: AmazonECS; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ClientException; Request ID: 44f47a4d-7fd5-40d0-97ac-55a7109fbbd1; Proxy: null)

  pulumi:pulumi:Stack (aws-native-python-dev):
    error: update failed

Resources:
    1 unchanged

Duration: 2s

warning: A new version of Pulumi is available. To upgrade from version '3.39.3' to '3.40.1', run
   $ brew upgrade pulumi
or visit https://pulumi.com/docs/reference/install/ for manual instructions and release notes.
```

### Expected Behavior

Based on [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), this is the only required parameter and the resource should be successfully created.  In reality, since more parameters are required by AWS, those should be marked as required in the documentation and Pulumi should provide an error before attempting to contact AWS.

For comparison, [here](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#inputs) is the equivalent documentation for the non-native package.  The container definitions list does indeed appear to be required, but interestingly the family does not.

### Actual Behavior

Pulumi attempted to create the resource and got back an error from the AWS API.

### Steps to reproduce

comment.body:
@jkisk Yep, I had read that.

> If the name property is not available on a resource, consult the [Registry](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/) for the specific resource you are creating. Some resources use a different property to override auto-naming. For instance, the aws.s3.Bucket type uses the property bucket instead of name.

And as far as I can tell from [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), that is the intent of `resource_name` in `TaskDefinition` - it's described as "the unique name of the resource".

Task definitions _do_ have user-assignable names in AWS, so it would make sense that this would be used from the field in Pulumi.  If this is one of the resources that only uses autogenerated ids, however, that should be clarified in the documentation and the actual usage of `resource_name` should be covered - since right now it appears to be entirely ignored and unused.

issue.title: Support PR reviews
issue.body:
Hi! Awesome action, thanks!

Have you considered also supporting PR reviews?

Instead of hiding the comment in the "Changed files" section, this also starts a review and posts it in the conversation, e.g.:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15199031/110950534-4004c000-8344-11eb-835a-55b32ce05fe7.png)

comment.body: One way to do this would be to hook up the linter to reviewdog; then the framework handles all the different logic for things like github reviews and all this code needs to do is run the translation layer between reviewdog and swiftlint.

cd into app directory

This shouldn't be necessary since it's our working directory already,
but it seems it is.

Copy all files into the image

This should fix mnmandahalf/github-actions-check-ecr-image-exists#1 and
be fairly future-proof in that whatever files are created, they'll be
included automatically.

Clean up shell script

There were a couple latent problems with spaces in the inputs, but most
importantly if the go script failed, this script would not fail, and
thus that failure wouldn't be passed back through to Actions.

We should probably remove the shell script entirely and just have the go
script output things in the right format, but this is the first easy
change.

issue.title: Action cannot find go file
issue.body:
When I run this action, I get this error:

```
stat ecr.go: no such file or directory
```

It looks like that file, and possibly the other golang files, needs to be `COPY`ed in the Dockerfile.

issue.title: Some mypy errors are ignored
issue.body:
I have a mypy error that looks like this:

```
importer/flows/helpers/__init__.py: error: Duplicate module named "helpers" (also at "<snip>")
```

Currently this gets ignored because it doesn't have the line and column numbers that `-efm="%f:%l:%c: %t%*[^:]: %m"` expects.

Tentatively https://github.com/winnielabs/action-mypy/commit/42d48176d9ec3333b0d78952e070471ba6d25882 fixes this, but I haven't really tested this thoroughly to see what other effects that has.

I'm suspecting that if mypy gets json output (as per #38), then that would fix this as well.  But the upstream PR is a year old now and there's no decision-making from the core mypy team about what would be needed for it to get merged, so I'm not hopeful about that happening soon.

commits.message:
Maybe fix support for some mypy errors

There are errors that don't include line number or column number, so
previously they would get silently ignored.  I _think_ this might fix
that.

Use our fork of reviewdog

See winnielabs/reviewdog@aa9fdaa for details.

issue.title: How does the plugin detect which task it has to be attached to?
issue.body:
I'm currently trying to implement the plugin into our Asana board

The main question really is how the github action can correctly attach itself to a certain task without using any kind of ID, or something?

How does it know to attach to a certain task instead of another one? Does it use the title for that or something like that? Or do we have to manually attach it using the "github PR" field inside the task?

comment.body: I _think_ it will attempt to attach to **every** Asana task url it finds in the description.  I haven't thoroughly tested this and I don't really understand typescript, but that matches what I've seen.

issue.title: Switch documentation from rst to md, improve examples and readability.
issue.body: Is there a good reason to use a Python-y doc format for a PHP project on github? Markdown seems like the natural choice.

comment.body:
To come back to this years later :), because Read The Docs was a good documentation-hosting site, it uses Sphinx, and Sphinx at the time only supported ReST.

Sphinx appears to have some level of markdown support these days, so that would be a thing to look into. Alternatively, mkdocs might be a sufficient replacement for RTD and could be published onto GitHub Pages. I don't know offhand what the api documentation story is for mkdocs.

issue.body:
### What happened?

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

### Expected Behavior

1. When doing `pulumi import`, I expected the generated code to be exactly matching the existing component in AWS and to not generate any warnings.
2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.
3. When executing the change, I expected it to not produce an error.
4. Importing a component should not put my stack in a state where I can no longer run my pulumi program without deleting my imported (and in use) resource.

comment.body: As a note, when `pulumi import` told me that the verification step had failed, I interpreted that as "you'll need to adjust the generated code in order to get it correctly generating a zero-diff configuration", not as "neither the generated code _nor_ the imported state will have the correct mapping of what's in aws, so you'll have to execute change operations on the aws api" (which I think is what happened).  Those are subtly different and the second is rather more dangerous, and if I'd understood that I would've aborted the import.  So there might be some clarity work to do on the warning message there.

I'm importing the first bits of our existing infrastructure into Pulumi.  Specifically, I'm trying to import the various definitions for an ALB so that I can add a new forwarding rule.

After importing the two Listeners, importing a ListenerRule that's attached to one of them produces code that does not associate the rule to the Listener.

Additionally, adding that association in code does not lead to a no-op state update, but that might be a mistake on my part.

### Steps to reproduce

Suspected minimal reproduction steps:

1. Create a listener for an application load balancer, including at least one rule, outside of Pulumi.
2. Import the listener.
3. Import a listener rule.

1. When doing `pulumi import`, I expected the generated code to be exactly matching the existing component in AWS and to not generate any warnings.
2. When adding the arn for the listener that I know the rule is attached to, I expected there to be no diff displayed in `pulumi up`.

fix(deps): update golang.org/x/build digest to 812c061

Fail noisily on GitHub token failures

This is a hacky fix for reviewdog/reviewdog#1210 and a partial revert of
reviewdog/reviewdog#411.

The logic for determining if a GitHub token is read-only is flawed.
Specifically it is looking to see if the PR is coming from a fork,
because in the past those were never supported.  That is no longer true,
as GitHub has added a setting to allow passing secrets to forks (which
you would do if all forks are trusted, like in a fork-based workflow
inside a company).

The idea itself is problematic because it's always going to require
keeping up to date with whatever logic GitHub is using on their backend,
so a "try it and see if it fails" approach would be more
forward-looking.

But beyond that, the entire idea of failing gracefully is an issue.  If
everything is configured correctly, great.  But if someone has
misconfigured the token, the only way they'd find out is if they go
digging into the logs on the Action; otherwise it just looks like it's
operating correctly and there are no linter warnings.  This is a problem
because it means we need to create additional monitoring on reviewdog to
see if it's working correctly, rather than just relying on the PR check
status and getting user reports when the job is failing.

An actual fix here would also strip out
`cienv.HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` and the library code that was
pulled in to handle this.  I don't know Go very well and so I've opted
to make the smallest hack I can to get this working for our situation
while waiting on the discussion about how to handle this upstream.

issue.title: reviewdog erroneously falls back to logging on forked repo even when it has write permissions
issue.body:
I'm debugging Github Actions jobs where the token has write permissions:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375476-b870b57a-b101-4921-95f5-5193d28083ce.png)

but reviewdog says it does not, and only logs messages:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/178375569-d862c5c1-4b87-4f16-ad59-10bf5d54f064.png)

I've traced this down in code.  The github-pr-review reporter [checks to see if the token is read-only](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cmd/reviewdog/main.go#L282-L287).  `HasReadOnlyPermissionGitHubToken` however [only checks to see if it's in a fork](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog/blob/master/cienv/github_actions.go#L115-L116).  However, github [now provides a way](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#modifying-the-permissions-for-the-github_token) to send write tokens to forks:

> You can use the `permissions` key to add and remove read permissions for forked repositories, but typically you can't grant write access. The exception to this behavior is where an admin user has selected the **Send write tokens to workflows from pull requests** option in the GitHub Actions settings.

So, we can't assume that all forks won't have write access; it needs to actually check the access of the token, or alternatively, try to post comments and if that fails then do the fallback action.

comment.body: @haya14busa I decided to take a look at trying to fix this myself. My conclusion is that we should probably just revert 2238fbd1063f5d1050b6e746cf0c611d213549d9. Graceful degredation is nice in theory, but in practice it means that the error is hidden. I had a pr that should have triggered comments via action-shellcheck, but there were no comments and everything was green: It's only when clicking into the Actions run and digging into the annotations that there's any indication that it _did_ find linter issues. If something is wrong with the Github tokens, no one is ever going to know unless the job starts failing. (And also there's the initial root issue reported here, which is that the check is incorrect and there actually _is_ permission in this case. But if we get rid of the check then that bypasses the bug.)

issue.title: Remove SSLv2 and SSLv3 support
issue.body:
This is a follow-up to #596 and the fix in #597.

Upstream [has removed support](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl/blob/main/CHANGELOG.rst#2210-2022-09-25) for SSLv2 and SSLv3.  Currently selenium-wire has a pinned version that prevents the upgrade, but sooner or later we'll want to be able to pull in updated versions.

In terms of the protocols, both of those are absolutely ancient.  TLS 1.0 was formally defined in 1999, and I think [all the browser vendors have killed off TLS 1.0 and 1.1](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/10/browser-vendors-unite-to-end-support-for-20-year-old-tls-1-0/) for a few years now - and those are the versions _after_ SSLv2 and v3!  When we look at [surveys of the internet](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssl-pulse/), practically no sites even support SSLv2 and v3 even if the clients did.  So I think it would be highly, highly unlikely that anyone would even notice that selenium-wire dropped support for those.

issue.title: Python type name inconsistency in documentation when used as an input
Class name inconsistency in documentation

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Needs attention from the triage team

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Some behavior is incorrect or out of spec

issue.body:
### What happened?

While creating an ECS Task Definition, the container definition class has two different names on the page and that makes it confusing as to which one to actually use.

### Steps to reproduce

On https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#container_definitions_python we see `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354134-c4c3c8c7-ecd5-4234-8942-97fd92477676.png)

When you click that and go to https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#taskdefinitioncontainerdefinition , that gives us the name `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` (without "Args"):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23369/191354261-d123248c-8f68-4022-aabb-8ab700c094ff.png)

It appears that `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs` is the name that works in code.

### Expected Behavior

Everything should use `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs`.

### Actual Behavior

There are instances of `TaskDefinitionContainerDefinition` on the page.

### Output of `pulumi about`

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Contributing

Vote on this issue by adding a 👍 reaction. 
To contribute a fix for this issue, leave a comment (and link to your pull request, if you've opened one already).

comment.body:
I thought I'd take a stab at updating this since stuff like this is usually pretty easy.  If I'm understanding the code correctly, though, it looks like there's one name used for an input class and one for an output class (not just in python, but the other languages as well).  And naming them to be the same, albeit defined in different files, seems like potentially a path towards problems.  I don't want to break actual code functionality if that's a convention used to separate the two different classes.

But if that's true, it would be nice if we could fix the leaky abstraction that's making its way through to the docs.

### What happened?

I identified that an ECS service I had defined was not working because I had forgotten to add [an execution IAM role](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task_execution_IAM_role.html).  Adding this to the Pulumi definition however produces an AWS API error.

        container_definitions=[

                image="amazon/amazon-ecs-sample",

issue.body:
### What happened?

I was trying to create a minimal ECS Task Definition for use in a bug report, and was using the documentation as a guide on what the smallest amount of code I needed to use was.  There however is a field not required by Pulumi nor marked as required in the docs, which is actually required by the AWS API.

### Steps to reproduce

Pulumi code:
```python3
ecs.TaskDefinition('this is required')
```
You can also clone https://github.com/xiongchiamiov/pulumi-bug-reports/tree/main/aws-native-python and call `ecs_task_definition.not_optional_arguments()` in `__main__.py`.

Pulumi run:
```
┌─[jamesph@Jamess-MBP] - [~/Documents/pulumi-bug-reports/aws-native-python] - [Mon Sep 19, 03:28]
└─[$]> pulumi up
Previewing update (dev)

View Live: https://app.pulumi.com/xiongchiamiov/aws-native-python/dev/previews/9a74a600-179a-4cb1-ace1-2d251c769261

     Type                              Name                   Plan
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       create

Resources:
    + 1 to create
    1 unchanged

Do you want to perform this update? yes
Updating (dev)

View Live: https://app.pulumi.com/xiongchiamiov/aws-native-python/dev/updates/4

     Type                              Name                   Status                  Info
     pulumi:pulumi:Stack               aws-native-python-dev  **failed**              1 error
 +   └─ aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition  this is required       **creating failed**     1 error

Diagnostics:
  aws-native:ecs:TaskDefinition (this is required):
    error: operation CREATE failed with "InvalidRequest": Invalid request provided: Create TaskDefinition: Container list cannot be empty. (Service: AmazonECS; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ClientException; Request ID: 44f47a4d-7fd5-40d0-97ac-55a7109fbbd1; Proxy: null)

  pulumi:pulumi:Stack (aws-native-python-dev):
    error: update failed

Resources:
    1 unchanged

Duration: 2s

warning: A new version of Pulumi is available. To upgrade from version '3.39.3' to '3.40.1', run
   $ brew upgrade pulumi
or visit https://pulumi.com/docs/reference/install/ for manual instructions and release notes.
```

### Expected Behavior

Based on [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), this is the only required parameter and the resource should be successfully created.  In reality, since more parameters are required by AWS, those should be marked as required in the documentation and Pulumi should provide an error before attempting to contact AWS.

For comparison, [here](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#inputs) is the equivalent documentation for the non-native package.  The container definitions list does indeed appear to be required, but interestingly the family does not.

### Actual Behavior

Pulumi attempted to create the resource and got back an error from the AWS API.

issue.body:
### What happened?

I'm creating a task definition for ECS and providing a human-readable resource name so that I can recognize task definitions while looking in the AWS console.

### Steps to reproduce

Here is my Pulumi code:

```python3
"""An AWS Python Pulumi program"""

import pulumi

task_definition = ecs.TaskDefinition(
    resource_name='winnie-web-task-{}'.format(pulumi.get_stack()),
    requires_compatibilities=['FARGATE'],
    cpu='1024',
    memory='2048',
    container_definitions=[
        ecs.TaskDefinitionContainerDefinitionArgs(
            name='nginx',
            image='755158074228.dkr.ecr.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/winnie-nginx:1.0.4',
            essential=True,
        ),
    ],
    network_mode='awsvpc',
    runtime_platform=ecs.TaskDefinitionRuntimePlatformArgs(

comment.body:
@jkisk Yep, I had read that.

> If the name property is not available on a resource, consult the [Registry](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/) for the specific resource you are creating. Some resources use a different property to override auto-naming. For instance, the aws.s3.Bucket type uses the property bucket instead of name.

And as far as I can tell from [the documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/aws-native/api-docs/ecs/taskdefinition/#create), that is the intent of `resource_name` in `TaskDefinition` - it's described as "the unique name of the resource".

Task definitions _do_ have user-assignable names in AWS, so it would make sense that this would be used from the field in Pulumi.  If this is one of the resources that only uses autogenerated ids, however, that should be clarified in the documentation and the actual usage of `resource_name` should be covered - since right now it appears to be entirely ignored and unused.
